challenges.title: Introduction to Basic CSS
description:
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) tell the browser how to display the text and other content that you write in HTML.

Note that CSS is case-sensitive so be careful with your capitalization.

CSS has been adopted by all major browsers and allows you to control:
  • color
  • fonts
  • positioning
  • spacing
  • sizing
  • decorations
  • transitions

There are three main ways to apply CSS styling. You can apply inline styles directly to HTML elements with the style attribute. Alternatively, you can place CSS rules within style tags in an HTML document. Finally, you can write CSS rules in an external style sheet, then reference that file in the HTML document. Even though the first two options have their uses, most developers prefer external style sheets because they keep the styles separate from the HTML elements. This improves the readability and reusability of your code.
In this section, you'll see how adding CSS styles to the elements of your FriendsPhotoApp can change it from simple text to something more.

challenges.title: Change the Color of Text
description: Now let's change the color of some of our text.
We can do this by changing the style of your h2 element.
The CSS property that is responsible for the color of an element's text is the "color" property.
Here's how you would set your h2 element's text color to blue:
<h2 style="color: blue;">FriendsPhotoApp</h2>
Note that it is a good practice to end inline style declarations with a ; .
<hr>
Change your h2 element's style so that its text color is red.
challengeSeed: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends? -- Abraham Lincoln
tests: assert($("h2").css("color") === "rgb(255, 0, 0)", 'message: Your h2 element should be red.');
assert(code.match(/\s*FriendsPhotoApp\s*<\/h2>/),' message: Your style declaration should end with a ; .');

challenges.title: Use CSS Selectors to Style Elements
description: With CSS, there are hundreds of CSS properties that you can use to change the way an element looks on your page.
When you entered <h2 style="color: red;">FriendsPhotoApp</h2>, you were giving that individual h2 element an inline style.
That's one way to add style to an element, but there's a better way to use CSS.
At the top of your code, create a style element like this:

<style>
</style>
Inside that style element, you can create a CSS selector for all h2 elements. For example, if you wanted all h2 elements to be red, your style element would look like this:

<style>
  h2 {
    color: red;
  }
</style>

Note that it's important to have both opening and closing curly braces ({ and }) around each element's style. You also need to make sure your element's style is between the opening and closing style tags. Finally, be sure to add the semicolon to the end of each of your element's styles.
<hr>
Delete your h2 element's style attribute and instead create a CSS style element. Add the necessary CSS to turn all h2 elements blue.
challengeSeed: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends? -- Abraham Lincoln
tests: assert(!$("h2").attr("style"), 'message: Remove the style attribute from your h2 element.');
assert($("style") && $("style").length > 1, 'message: Create a style element.');
assert($("h2").css("color") === "rgb(0, 0, 255)", 'message: Your h2 element should be blue.');
assert(code.match(/h2\s*\{\s*color\s*:.*;\s*\}/g), 'message: Ensure that your stylesheet h2 declaration is valid with a semicolon and closing brace.');
assert(code.match(/<\/style>/g) && code.match(/<\/style>/g).length === (code.match(//g) || []).length, 'message: Make sure all your style elements are valid and have a closing tag.');

challenges.title: Use a CSS Class to Style an Element
description: Classes are reusable styles that can be added to HTML elements.

Here's an example CSS class declaration that might be used for some introductory text. Note that the class name of "preface" is not special. It is up to you to choose any class name you would like that describes the purpose of the style.

<style>
  .preface {
    color: blue;
  }
</style>
You can see that we've created a CSS class called preface within the <style> tag.
You can apply a class to an HTML element like this:
<h2 class="preface">FriendsPhotoApp</h2>
Note that in your CSS style element, classes should start with a period. In your HTML elements' class declarations, classes should not start with a period.
<hr>
Inside your style element, change the h2 selector to .intro and update the color's value from blue to red.
Give your h2 element the class attribute with a value of 'intro'.
challengeSeed: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends? -- Abraham Lincoln
tests: assert($("h2").css("color") === "rgb(255, 0, 0)", 'message: Your h2 element should be red.');
assert($("h2").hasClass("intro"), 'message: Your h2 element should have the class intro.');
assert(code.match(/\.intro\s*\{\s*color\s*:\s*red;\s*\}/g), 'message: Your stylesheet should declare a intro class and have its color set to red.');
assert($("h2").attr("style") === undefined, 'message: Do not use inline style declarations like style="color: red" in your h2 element.');

challenges.title: Set the id of an Element
description: In addition to classes, each HTML element can also have an id attribute.
There are several benefits to using id attributes: You can use an id to style a single element and later you'll learn that you can use them to select and modify specific elements with JavaScript.
id attributes should be unique. Browsers won't enforce this, but it is a widely agreed upon best practice. So please don't give more than one element the same id attribute.
Here's an example of how you give your h2 element the id of friends-photo-app:
<h2 id="friends-photo-app">
<hr>

challenges.title: Use an id Attribute to Style an Element
description: One cool thing about id attributes is that, like classes, you can style them using CSS.

However, an id is not reusable and should only be applied to one element. An id also has a higher specificity (importance) than a class so if both are applied to the same element and have conflicting styles, the styles of the id will be applied.
Here's an example of how you can take your element with the id attribute of friends-photo-main and give it the background color of green. In your style element:

#friends-photo-main {
  background-color: green;
}
Note that inside your style element, you always reference classes by putting a . in front of their names. You always reference ids by putting a # in front of their names.
<hr>

Try giving your div, which now has the id attribute of friends-photo-main, a Plum background. Remember the div also has a class of .main-content. Notice which of the colors is applied. Does the class with the silver background, or the id with the Plum background have priority?

challenges.title: Centering text and images
description: Now let's try centering some things. Centering in CSS is a topic with a lot to cover, so this is just an introduction and we will see more about it in later lessons.
Usually you don't center HTML elements themselves, you need to style the parent element to center all the elements inside the parent.
One way to center align text and images is to use the text-align property, like in the example below:

<style>
  .container {
    text-align: center;
  }
</style>

<div class="container">
  <p>Inside div; centered</p>
</div>

<p>Outside; not centered.</p>

challenges.title: Adjust the Padding of an Element
description: Now let's put our Friends Photo App away for a little while and learn more about styling HTML.

You may have already noticed this, but all HTML elements are essentially little boxes and each box takes up some horizontal and vertical space on the page, also known as the width and height of the element.
Each box is made up of four parts. We already know what content is from previous challenges. The other three properties that determine the size of the box are: padding, margin, and border.
The margin and the padding are invisible. If a border is specified you can usually see it.
An element's padding controls the amount of space between the element's content and the element's border.

Compare the above diagram with our code. We can see that the blue box and the red box are nested within the yellow box. Note that the red box has more padding than the blue box. Also note the border is black and surrounds each box.
When you increase the blue box's padding, it will increase the distance between the content "lorem ipsum" and the border around the content.
<hr>
Change the padding of your blue box to match that of your red box.
tests: assert($(".blue-box").css("padding-top") === "20px", 'message: Your blue-box class should give elements 20px of padding.');

challenges.title: Adjust the Margin of an Element
description: An element's margin controls the amount of invisible space outside of an element. In other words, the amount of space between the border and other surrounding elements.
Here, we can see that the blue box and the red box are nested within the yellow box. Note that the red box has more margin than the blue box, making it appear smaller.
When you increase the blue box's margin, it will increase the distance between its border and surrounding elements.
<hr>
Change the margin of the blue box to match that of the red box.
tests: assert($(".blue-box").css("margin-top") === "30px", 'message: Your blue-box class should give elements 30px of margin.');

challenges.title: Use Clockwise Notation to Specify the Padding of an Element
description: Instead of specifying an element's padding-top, padding-right, padding-bottom, and padding-left properties, you can specify them all in one line, like this:

These four values work like a clock: top, right, bottom, left, and will produce the exact same result as using the side-specific padding instructions.
<hr>
Use Clockwise Notation to give the ".blue-box" class a padding of 40px on its top and left side, but only 20px on its bottom and right side.

assert($(".blue-box").css("padding-left") === "40px", 'message: Your blue-box class should give the left of elements 40px of padding.');
assert(!/padding-top|padding-right|padding-bottom|padding-left/.test(code), 'message: You should use the clockwise notation to set the padding of blue-box class.');
